docs.lead_paragraph: A baby pygmy sperm whale that washed ashore at Far Rockaway a week ago was reported "very much better." A spokesman at the New York Aquarium, where attendants have been feeding the whale since its mother died last Tuesday, said the 40-pound calf was "eating more," giving it "each day a better chance" for survival.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration disclosed plans yesterday to make New York City more attractive by planting $265,000 worth of flowers along main streets, in public plazas and around public buildings.
docs.abstract: NYC Health Services Admr Chase repts waiting time for mental-competency exams for defendants in NYC's Manhattan Criminal and State (NYS) Sup Ct has been cut from 4 to 2 wks in most cases; says gain allows defendants to meet all ct-appearance dates and cuts ct congestion; credits reforms at ct clinics set up in Sept '71
docs.snippet: The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration disclosed plans yesterday to make New York City more attractive by planting $265,000 worth of flowers along main streets, in public plazas and around public buildings.

docs.lead_paragraph: JONESBORO, Me., Sept. 30 -- The clam flats off Roque Bluffs, deserted since Sept. 16 when the entire coast of Maine was declared polluted by the "red tide," a poisonous algae, were peopled with diggers again today.

headline.main: The 'Red Tide' Leaves Clam Diggers Destitute; Most of Maine Coast Opened, But Many Need Long-Term Aid

docs.abstract: article describes hardships imposed on Maine clam diggers as result of ban on harvesting of softshell clams because of contamination by red tide; Nixon's declaration of red tide as natl disaster on Sept 28 makes diggers eligible for relief payments; diggers fear public will be wary of eating clams and other shellfish for many months; illus
docs.snippet: JONESBORO, Me., Sept. 30 -- The clam flats off Roque Bluffs, deserted since Sept. 16 when the entire coast of Maine was declared polluted by the "red tide," a poisonous algae, were peopled with diggers again today.

byline.original: By HOMER BIGARTSpecial to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Battle of the Sexes is rarely fought more vigorously or won more convincingly than among the wrasse, a type of small, iridescent blue fish that lives in the waters of Australia's Great Barrier Reef.

headline.main: Life and Death in The Sea Around Us; Fish Stories

docs.abstract: comment on pygmy sperm whales washed ashore at Far Rockaway Beach and taken to NY Aquarium; notes measures taken to save whales' lives; illus
docs.snippet: The Battle of the Sexes is rarely fought more vigorously or won more convincingly than among the wrasse, a type of small, iridescent blue fish that lives in the waters of Australia's Great Barrier Reef.
